awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Salt marsh restorations: a structured experiment for learning and teaching about salt marshes, microbial diversity, and ecosystem function
awd_abstract_narration:
Salt marshes have received a great deal of attention recently because they provide a number of essential ecosystem services, including carbon sequestration and nitrogen removal. Strong interest in marshes as carbon sinks is likely to spur new programs to offset carbon emissions by restoring degraded wetlands, raising a host of questions concerning whether marsh restorations can successfully rehabilitate other ecosystem functions.  A key ecosystem functions of salt marshes is their ability to remove biologically available nitrogen through a microbial process known as denitrification.  Biologically available nitrogen is entering coastal ecosystems at increasing rates as a result of human activities such as application of fertilizers and combustion of fossil fuels. When this nitrogen makes its way to coastal waters it can result in a host of negative environmental effects associated with eutrophication, including increasing areas of low oxygen water known as coastal dead zones.  The microbes living in salt marshes are able to remove portions of this excess biologically available nitrogen by converting it back to nitrogen gas, suggesting a benefit of salt marsh restoration, however, more information is needed regarding how these microbes may respond to environmental changes associated with restoration.  This study will provide new insight on how restoration of a New England salt marsh will alter the capacity of the marsh to remove biologically available nitrogen and will increase understanding of the physiology of the microbes that underlie this critical biogeochemical pathway through a combination of in situ rate measurements, environmental metagenomics, and whole genome sequencing. 

The results of this research will provide important new information to restoration practitioners on the conditions that are mostly likely to successfully restore the denitrification capacity of degraded salt marshes so that they reach parity with undisturbed marshes.  This work will also enhance scientific infrastructure and knowledge transfer through two mechanisms.  First, it will train one early career female scientist, a postdoctoral scholar, and two graduate students.  Second, research on the denitrification capacity of salt marshes will be incorporated into a First Year Seminar for undergraduate students at the University of Massachusetts Boston, the only public university in the city, which serves a large minority and first generation college student population.  This seminar program is designed to increase retention of at risk biology majors by engaging them in research experiences in the early days of their college career. Through collaborations with the Massachusetts Department of Ecological Restoration, the students will meet with stakeholders, design and carry out research in recently restored marshes in the greater Boston area, and report their findings back to the stakeholders. This community-engaged scholarship provides a unique mechanism to disseminate information to stakeholders and it engages students in the scientific process in a way that promotes accountability, generates higher quality outcomes and excites them about the field of ecology.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Salt marshes are critically important habitats that provide essential ecosystem services to coastal communities, including filtering and removing nutrient pollution, providing storage for carbon, and protecting upland communities from sea level rise and storm surges.  Despite these important services, salt marshes are under siege from a diverse array of threats including habitat loss via invasive species and human population expansion, and from nutrient pollution, sea level rise, and alteration to associated aquatic and terrestrial food webs.  Conservation and restoration of these critical habitats will be essential for the maintenance of their ecosystem services, however, there are critical aspects of salt marsh restoration where additional knowledge can advance restoration goals.  The purposes of this research was to examine the role that microbial communities play in marsh restoration and marsh biogeochemical cycling. 

Intellectual merit

We developed several key insights from this work that can inform management of coastal marshes.  First, we identified significant differences in the microbes found among the roots of native plants, compared to their invasive counterparts, within the important marsh invasive plant, the common reed (Phragmites australis). This suggests that there are specific microbes that might promote invasion success, allowing invasive species to outcompete their native counterparts. Second, we showed that during passive restoration, the sediment microbial and fungal communities become increasingly more similar to references marshes after restoration than they were prior to restoration. Further, these results show that shifts in microbial community structure begin to occur prior to the restoration of marsh vegetation, which indicates that the characteristics of the soil after restoration are more important than the plant species at explaining changes to the microbial community. The results of this work suggest that assessing microbial shifts could provide an early alert system for detecting whether marsh restorations are successfully tracking a return to reference conditions.

This work also focused on understanding how nutrient supply and other marsh conditions alters the cycling of carbon and nitrogen in these environments. We show that the form of nitrogen that gets added to marshes plays an important role in understanding the consequences of that nitrogen enrichment. The growth of salt marsh vegetation is limited by the supply of nitrogen, so nitrogen pollution can promote plant growth. However, if that nitrogen is added in the form of nitrate, there are two possible outcomes, it can be taken up by the plants to support primary production, or, microbes can use it instead of oxygen to support their growth and respiration. This matters because the former outcome promotes plant growth, which facilitates sediment trapping, promotes carbon storage, and helps marshes to keep pace with sea level rise.  However, the latter outcome results in increases in microbial respiration, which converts available organic matter back into carbon dioxide, which can escape to the atmosphere. Further, this enhanced decomposition, could make it harder for marshes to keep pace with accelerating sea level rise.  

Broader impacts

In addition to publication and presentation to the scientific community, we also disseminating the findings of this work through multiple avenues aimed at broadening participation, including through the development of a Data Nugget for use in high school biology courses and through the translation of one of our papers for publication in the Science Journal for Teens.  This research directly trained several undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral scholars from both University of Massachusetts Boston and Northeastern University. This included the development of a January term research immersion course for students from marginalized groups. The research performed in these immersion courses were published in three different manuscripts with participant as coauthors.
